items.body:

Cannot perform prediction on the new data gives an error: 

AttributeError: 'DataFrame' object has no attribute 'feature_names'

Code for reference:

num_round = 7000
param_grid = {'tree_method': 'gpu_hist', 
              'max_depth': 3, 
              'learning_rate': 0.01,
              'subsample':0.8,
              'colsample_bytree':0.8,
              'min_child_weight':1,
              'alpha':5,
              'predictor':'gpu_predictor'}
param_grid['nthread'] = 10

dtrain = xgb.DMatrix(trans_train_x, label=train_y)
dtest = xgb.DMatrix(trans_valid_x, label=valid_y)

with open("model.pkl", "wb") as fp:
    pickle.dump(bst, fp)

The trans_train_x and trans_valid_x are one hot encoded train and validation datasets.

items.title: Boosting rounds missing from XGBClassifier docs
items.body:
The docs for `XGBClassifier` (https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python/python_api.html#xgboost.XGBClassifier) do not have any parameter corresponding to the number of boosting rounds.

As far as I am aware, the number of boosting rounds is still controllable when using `binary:logistic` loss, and if I'm not mistaken, that XGBClassifier class should just be a wrapper around XGBModel (https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/674c409e9d24b496d925781a3345b626efbf9dd9/python-package/xgboost/sklearn.py#L201), which does support an `n_estimators` parameter.

items.title: Add arbitrary fieldname in set_float_info
items.body:
In #2255 the same question was asked but the issue was closed with no resolution. 
Since then at least 2 new metainfo was added to the package: labels_lower_bound_ and labels_upper_bound_. 
[https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/dev/classxgboost_1_1MetaInfo.html](https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/stable/dev/classxgboost_1_1MetaInfo.html)
These new metainfo fields let xgboost to calculate survival models.

In my case I need to add additional logic to the calculation in my custom loss. I can trick the system by passing my data through the labels_lower_bound and labels_upper_bound, but it's not nice at all and I was wondering if I needed a third parameter for my calculation. 

Is it possible to add any field name and reference them in the custom loss with their name?

The documentation doesn't mention any restriction on field names.
https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python/python_api.html#xgboost.DMatrix.set_float_info

items.title: Should we tune only colsample_bynode instead of multiple colsample_by*
items.body:
Hi, all

xgboost provides us three colsample_by* : colsample_bytree, colsample_bylevel, colsample_bynode and saying that "colsample_by* parameters work cumulatively. For instance, the combination {'colsample_bytree':0.5, 'colsample_bylevel':0.5, 'colsample_bynode':0.5} with 64 features will leave 8 features to choose from at each split."

Thus, it seems that users should directly tune colsample_bynode instead of all three, in order to reduce tuning search space. What's drawback of doing this??

Also, [random forest tutorial](https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials/rf.html#standalone-random-forest-with-xgboost-api) seems to support my argument above because it also only uses colsample_bynode. Isn't colsample_by* learnt from random forest?

Thanks for any help.

items.title: xgboost.dask.DaskXGBClassifier implementation of .predict() does not adhere to the sklearn API specification
items.body:
[Sklearn Specification for Classifiers](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/developers/develop.html#specific-models)

The `.predict()` method of `xgboost.dask.DaskXGBClassifier` currently returns probabilities. Per the specification, the `.predict()` method is supposed to return class labels. This is also inconsistent with the behavior of the `.predict()` method of `xgboost.XGBClassifier`, which properly returns class labels.

Other functionality in `dask` (specifically in `dask_ml.model_selection`) depend on the behavior being correct.

Example of correct behavior in `xgboost.XGBClassifier`:

```
import xgboost as xgb
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification

X, y = make_classification(n_samples=1000, n_informative=5, n_classes=2, random_state=1234)
clf = xgb.XGBClassifier(objective="binary:logistic")
clf.fit(X, y)
print(clf.predict(X)[:5])
# [0 0 1 1 1]
```

Example of incorrect behavior in `xgboost.dask.DaskXGBClassifier`:

```
import xgboost as xgb
import dask.dataframe as dd
import dask.distributed
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification


cluster = dask.distributed.LocalCluster(n_workers=2, threads_per_worker=1)
client = dask.distributed.Client(cluster)
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=1000, n_informative=5, n_classes=2, random_state=1234)
X_ = dd.from_array(X, chunksize=500)
y_ = dd.from_array(y, chunksize=500)
clf = xgb.dask.DaskXGBClassifier(objective="binary:logistic")
clf.fit(X_, y_)
print(clf.predict(X_).compute()[:5])
# [0.03111755 0.00773133 0.99876463 0.99792993 0.9944484 ]
```

items.title: Incorrect array shape returned by xgboost.dask.predict on multiclass predictions
items.body:
The function `xgboost.dask.predict` assumes that the shape of it's output is always `(n_rows, )`, but for multiclass classification it would be `(n_rows, n_classes)`.

Here's a minimum working example:
```
import xgboost as xgb
import dask.dataframe as dd
import dask.distributed
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.datasets import make_classification


cluster = dask.distributed.LocalCluster(n_workers=2, threads_per_worker=1)
client = dask.distributed.Client(cluster)
X, y = make_classification(n_samples=1000, n_informative=5, n_classes=3)
X_ = dd.from_array(X, chunksize=500)
y_ = dd.from_array(y, chunksize=500)
dtrain = xgb.dask.DaskDMatrix(client, data=X_, label=y_)

model = xgb.dask.train(
    client,
    {"objective": "multi:softprob", "num_class": 3},
    dtrain=dtrain
)

preds = xgb.dask.predict(client, model, dtrain)

print("Dask inferred shape: ", preds.shape)
print("Computed shape: ", preds.compute().shape)
```


The offending line is [this one](https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/9c6e791e64afc8b10365ecc1ec2914dbe3b6554c/python-package/xgboost/dask.py#L778)

I don't know what the maintainers would consider an idiomatic solution, but something like this works (but is gross). I'm not familiar enough with the serialized configuration to know if those keys exist for other learners/if a `KeyError` would be raised by some set of params that I'm unfamiliar with.

```
import json

...

def predict():
    ...
        
    arrays = []
    cfg = json.loads(booster.save_config())
    pred_dim = int(cfg["learner"]["learner_model_param"].get("num_class", 1))

    for i, shape in enumerate(shapes):
        if pred_dim > 1:
            pred_shape = (shape[0], pred_dim)
        else:
            pred_shape = (shape[0], )

        arrays.append(da.from_delayed(results[i], shape=pred_shape,
                                      dtype=numpy.float32))
    predictions = await da.concatenate(arrays, axis=0)


```

Happy to provide any clarifications if this isn't clear enough.

items.title: set min_child_weight as a float instead of int
items.body:
Hi, all

Based on xgboost documentation, min_child_weight is treated as number of observation for rmse objective and is usually chosen as int such as https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/python/python_api.html#xgboost.XGBRegressor.

However, I recently read a article saying that "With XGBoost, you can specify this parameter as a float as well. If you do, it will use a percentage of samples to determine leaf nods." (https://kevinvecmanis.io/machine%20learning/hyperparameter%20tuning/dataviz/python/2019/05/11/XGBoost-Tuning-Visual-Guide.html#child_weight). I cannot find a second source using min_child_weight as a float.

So I am confused and worried that is it true that we could set min_child_weight as a float?? Any comfirmation would be appreciated.

items.title: Some multi-GPU unit tests hang when running in a different Docker environment
items.body:
https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/pull/5873#issuecomment-666696157
Log from 4-process setup:
```
pid = 21916, Device = 0
pid = 21919, Device = 0
pid = 21921, Device = 0
pid = 21924, Device = 0
```
~even though here we should have been using 4 GPUs.~ See https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/issues/5963#issuecomment-666721876.

The undefined behavior exists in following tests:
* `tests/python-gpu/test_gpu_with_dask.py::TestDistributedGPU::test_dask_array`
* `tests/distributed/runtests-gpu.sh`

The behavior is "undefined" in the sense that using a different Docker container causes the tests to fail, even though they were succeeding previously.

Passing (current CI setup):
```bash
tests/ci_build/ci_build.sh gpu_build_centos6 docker --build-arg CUDA_VERSION=10.0 \
  tests/ci_build/build_via_cmake.sh  -DUSE_CUDA=ON -DUSE_NCCL=ON \
  -DOPEN_MP:BOOL=ON -DHIDE_CXX_SYMBOLS=ON -DGPU_COMPUTE_VER=75
```

items.title: Model returns different results for scipy sparse matrix and scipy.sparse.toarray()  numpy ndarray.
items.body:
I have a pipeLine that includes TfidfVectorizer AND XGBoost model.

```python
class Text2TfIdfTransformer(BaseEstimator):

    def __init__(self):
        self._model = TfidfVectorizer()
        pass

    def fit(self, df_x, df_y=None):
        df_x = df_x.apply(lambda x : clean_text(x))
        self._model.fit(df_x)
        return self

    def transform(self, df_x):
        return self._model.transform(df_x)

xgb_tf_idf = Pipeline(steps=[('tfidf',Text2TfIdfTransformer()),
                         ('xgboost', xgb.XGBClassifier(objective='multi:softmax', n_jobs=8))])
```

now, when I obtain intermediate tfidf result and pass  it to the model:

```python
vec = tfidf.transform(['include stdio h int main'])
arr = vec.toarray()

vec == arr                 # True

xgb_tf_idf .predict(vec)    !=     xgb_tf_idf .predict(arr)       
```


The predict proba method also differs and results are off by a lot. Am I doing something wrong or is this a bug ? 

Thanks

items.title: Custom multiclass eval metric receives transformed predictions
items.body:
Hi,

I'm having issues with custom multiclass objective function's eval metric, as the eval always receives transformed predictions, e.g. the argmax value, not the raw predictions.
It was stated in issue #4288 that we can use the example from [xgboost/demo/guide-python/custom_softmax.py](xgboost/demo/guide-python/custom_softmax.py) but to me it's not clear how to use custom predict function for eval metric. 

If you can show how to use it correctly I would appreciate much. 

Thanks

items.title: [R] Cannot set weights per query group when learning to rank
items.body:
The `setinfo()` currently throws error if the length of the given weight vector is not equal to the number of rows in the data:

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/8b1afce316b5b600bd8a8d09c460248b1a26b758/R-package/R/xgb.DMatrix.R#L259-L264

This check is incompatible with learning to rank, since when learning to rank, we assign weights to query groups, not individual data rows. Thus, it's currently not possible to perform weighted ranking in the R package.

items.title: [BLOCKING] [R] Two R methods discards errors from C API functions
items.body:
C API functions indicate errors by their return values. All callers of C API functions should check the return value and handle error if the return value is -1. There are two places in `R-package/src/xgboost_R.cc` where this is not done:

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/a4de2f68e492065f5b90e83789a65388d349f0df/R-package/src/xgboost_R.cc#L376-L381

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/a4de2f68e492065f5b90e83789a65388d349f0df/R-package/src/xgboost_R.cc#L398-L405

These function calls should have been wrapped with `CHECK_CALL()` macro to handle errors. Currently, errors from these two functions are silently discarded.

In #5794, the error message was cryptic
```
  [06:35:16] amalgamation/../src/learner.cc:506: Check failed: mparam_.num_feature != 0 (0 vs. 0) : 0 feature is supplied.  Are you using raw Booster interface?
Stack trace:
  [bt] (0) /home/redacted/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(dmlc::LogMessageFatal::~LogMessageFatal()+0x64) [0x7f2da04ae154]
  [bt] (1) /home/redacted/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(xgboost::LearnerConfiguration::ConfigureNumFeatures()+0xf0) [0x7f2da054d220]
  [bt] (2) /home/redacted/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(xgboost::LearnerConfiguration::Configure()+0x356) [0x7f2da05aaba6]
  [bt] (3) /home/redacted/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(xgboost::LearnerImpl::Predict(std::shared_ptr<xgboost::DMatrix>, bool, xgboost::HostDeviceVector<float>*, unsigned int, bool, bool, bool, bool, bool)+0x7d) [0x7f2da0569e1d]
  [bt] (4) /home/redacted/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(XGBoosterPredict+0xf0) [0x7f2da04c27e0]
  [bt] (5) /home/redacted/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(XGBoosterPredict_R+0x89) [0x7f2da04a9799]
  [bt] (6) /opt/R/3.6.3/lib/R/lib/libR.so(+0x131bdd) [0x7f2dcf047bdd]
  [bt] (7) /opt/R/3.6.3/lib/R/lib/libR.so(Rf_eval+0x380) [0x7f2dcf051580]
  [bt] (8) /opt/R/3.6.3/lib/R/lib/libR.so(+0x13d121) [0x7f2dcf053121]
```
This message is misleading, as it sounds as if the error had occurred in the prediction function. In fact, the real error occurred earlier, when the model was loaded. When I inserted `CHECK_CALL()` macro in `R-package/src/xgboost_R.cc`, I got the correct error message:
```
Error in xgb.unserialize(modelfile) : 
  [03:19:04] ../src/learner.cc:864: Check failed: header == serialisation_header_: 

  If you are loading a serialized model (like pickle in Python) generated by older
  XGBoost, please export the model by calling `Booster.save_model` from that version
  first, then load it back in current version.  There's a simple script for helping
  the process. See:

    https://xgboost.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorials/saving_model.html

  for reference to the script, and more details about differences between saving model and
  serializing.


Stack trace:
  [bt] (0) /home/phcho/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(dmlc::LogMessageFatal::~LogMessageFatal()+0x7c) [0x7f1f596f737c]
  [bt] (1) /home/phcho/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(xgboost::LearnerIO::Load(dmlc::Stream*)+0x81b) [0x7f1f5980bc3b]
  [bt] (2) /home/phcho/R/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu-library/3.6/xgboost/libs/xgboost.so(XGBoosterUnserializeFromBuffer+0x8c) [0x7f1f596faaec]
```

items.title: Make json configuration locale-independent
items.body:
Custom json serialization like  https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/970b4b3fa2001e389910d3f6fe2af0a2966c3bd7/src/learner.cc#L102 
is fragile 

```
import locale
import xgboost
import numpy as np
locale.setlocale(locale.LC_ALL, 'sk_SK')
model = xgboost.XGBClassifier(booster='gblinear')
X = np.random.rand(100,10)
y = np.random.rand(100) > 0.5
model.fit(X, y)
print(model)
print(model.get_booster().save_config())
model.fit(X, y)
```

```

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "ab375d69-e91a-4c07-b83b-96afdaa201cc_afterxgbobj.dat.py", line 13, in <module>
    model.fit(X, y)
  File "/home/sh1ng/dev/h2oai_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/xgboost/sklearn.py", line 824, in fit
    callbacks=callbacks)
  File "/home/sh1ng/dev/h2oai_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/xgboost/training.py", line 212, in train
    xgb_model=xgb_model, callbacks=callbacks)
  File "/home/sh1ng/dev/h2oai_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/xgboost/training.py", line 75, in _train_internal
    bst.update(dtrain, i, obj)
  File "/home/sh1ng/dev/h2oai_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/xgboost/core.py", line 1369, in update
    dtrain.handle))
  File "/home/sh1ng/dev/h2oai_env/lib/python3.6/site-packages/xgboost/core.py", line 190, in _check_call
    raise XGBoostError(py_str(_LIB.XGBGetLastError()))
xgboost.core.XGBoostError: Some trailing characters could not be parsed: ',500000'
```

The problem is `base_score` value set to `0,500000`

I'd recommend to use well tested third party component for json, although it may look simple at the first glance it's quite challenging to implement it properly.

items.title: sparkxgb.zip is outdated
items.body:
I'm trying to use XGBOOST with Pyspark where some websites pointed to the sparkxgb.zip provided by this Github respository. 

My code is as follows:
I import the `sparkxgb.zip` as follows: 
```
spark.sparkContext.addPyFile("sparkxgb.zip")
```
However it results in the following error when I try to import the classifier. 
I think some updates are needed because some packages defined in the zip file can't be imported from `pyspark.ml.util`

items.body:
Thanks for participating in the XGBoost community! We use https://discuss.xgboost.ai for any general usage questions and discussions. The issue tracker is used for actionable items such as feature proposals discussion, roadmaps, and bug tracking.  You are always welcomed to post on the forum first :)

Issues that are inactive for a period of time may get closed. We adopt this policy so that we won't lose track of actionable issues that may fall at the bottom of the pile. Feel free to reopen a new one if you feel there is an additional problem that needs attention when an old one gets closed.

For bug reports, to help the developer act on the issues, please include a description of your environment, preferably a minimum script to reproduce the problem.

For feature proposals, list clear, small actionable items so we can track the progress of the change.

items.title: This may not be accurate due to some parameters are only used in language bindings but passed down to XGBoost core.  Or some parameters are not used but slip through this verification. Please open an issue if you find above cases.
items.body:
Basically I moved everything to my Linux (centos 8) server, then this pops out:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11748629/87850382-69d72580-c922-11ea-80f7-30085d51961c.png)

(There is no such warnings when I run it on my windows laptop)

However, the param `verbose_eval` seems to be working right...

items.title: Include libxgboost4j.dylib (MacOS) in Snapshot JARs
items.body:
Hi guys,

I'm testing your library and comparing the results between Java and Python libraries.
I'm seeing significant differences with the Python library being a lot better on my test data.
The only difference I found was the version of the underlying Xgboost library (the cc classes).
There are some commits for which I'm waiting in the Java version, e.g. 

Fix pruner. (#5335)

* Honor the tree depth.
* Prevent pruning pruned node. https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/commit/e0509b330734c1d6ee32b843c273a6934df24319#diff-cd7e3f1e4c39ef6c389c09dd7cecddbd

Can you please create a new release to Maven Central with the current version? I would be very grateful!! 

Thank you in advance :)

items.title: [Feature proposal] Support RAPIDS Memory Manager (RMM)
items.body:
RAPIDS is a GPU based data analytics framework developed by NVIDIA. A typical all-GPU workflow is to use RAPIDS cudf to read data and create features, and then use xgboost GPU to train. The two libraries end up competing for memory on the GPU and could lead to OOM since device memory is often limited on GPU.

To mitigate this issue, I propose that xgboost supports [RMM: RAPIDS Memory Manager](https://github.com/rapidsai/rmm) as an alternative memory allocator and share memory pool with other RAPIDS libraries.

items.title: [BUG] XGBoost.dask.predict returning an incompatible dask_cudf Series
items.body:
**Bug Description**
I am trying to subtract the results from XGBoost.dask.predict with another dask_cudf Series but that's giving an error. I realize that it's because each individual partition is not mapped as a cuda Series. I am able to solve it if I separately run map_partitions to map each partitions as a cuda series. It will good to do this internally in XGBoost.dask.predict before returning the result. 

Here is code snippet to reproduce the bug:

```
%%time 
size = 1000000
npartitions = 8
cdf = cudf.DataFrame({'x': np.random.randint(0, npartitions, size=size), 'y': np.random.normal(size=size)})
ddf = dask_cudf.from_cudf(cdf,npartitions=npartitions)

dtrain = xgb.dask.DaskDMatrix(client, X_train, Y_train)
```

items.title: [Doc] [R] Discourage use of saveRDS() for long-term, archival storage of models
items.body:
We do our best to ensure that models from older versions of XGBoost can be read into newer versions of XGBoost (**"backward compatibility"**). Our automated testing farm has a suite of tests to ensure backward compatibility.

It has been reported that the Booster object saved with `saveRDS()` function in R cannot be read back if XGBoost is upgraded. See #5794. In short, technical limitation of `saveRDS()` is such that the generated RDS file is not backward compatible.

The documentation needs to be clarified for better user experience. Couple things:
1. **Point out that `saveRDS()` is a short-term temporary storage.** Use `xgb.save()` for long-term storage.
2. **Start promoting JSON format.** It's more robust, and besides, in the worst case one can always use jsonlite or the like to manually parse the model.
3. **Provide migration examples / scripts.** Something like #5794, where users can gently transition from `saveRDS()` to long-term storage. See https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/issues/5794#issuecomment-645254796, which shows an example script to convert an RDS file from 0.90 to JSON format (1.1.0+).

items.title: [R] [ci] R linters are not being run in CI
items.body:
I tried to pick up part of #5779 tonight, and realized something...I believe that the R linting tests are not being run in CI.

I confirmed this by copying those linters used in `test_lint.R` into the following script

<details><summary>lintr script (click me)</summary>

```r
library(lintr)

args <- commandArgs(
    trailingOnly = TRUE
)
SOURCE_DIR <- args[[1L]]

FILES_TO_LINT <- list.files(
    path = SOURCE_DIR
    , pattern = "\\.r$"
    , all.files = TRUE
    , ignore.case = TRUE
    , full.names = TRUE
    , recursive = TRUE
    , include.dirs = FALSE
)

LINTERS_TO_USE <- list(
    absolute_paths_linter=lintr::absolute_paths_linter
    , assignment_linter=lintr::assignment_linter
    , closed_curly_linter=lintr::closed_curly_linter
    , commas_linter=lintr::commas_linter
    , infix_spaces_linter=lintr::infix_spaces_linter
    , line_length_linter=lintr::line_length_linter
    , no_tab_linter=lintr::no_tab_linter
    , object_usage_linter=lintr::object_usage_linter
    , object_length_linter=lintr::object_length_linter
    , open_curly_linter=lintr::open_curly_linter
    , spaces_inside_linter=lintr::spaces_inside_linter
    , spaces_left_parentheses_linter=lintr::spaces_left_parentheses_linter
    , trailing_blank_lines_linter=lintr::trailing_blank_lines_linter
    , trailing_whitespace_linter=lintr::trailing_whitespace_linter
    , true_false=lintr::T_and_F_symbol_linter
)

cat(sprintf("Found %i R files to lint\n", length(FILES_TO_LINT)))

results <- NULL

for (r_file in FILES_TO_LINT) {

    this_result <- lintr::lint(
        filename = r_file
        , linters = LINTERS_TO_USE
        , cache = FALSE
    )

    print(
        sprintf(
            "Found %i linting errors in %s"
            , length(this_result)
            , r_file
        )
        , quote = FALSE
    )

    results <- c(results, this_result)

}

issues_found <- length(results)

if (issues_found > 0L) {
    print(results)
}

quit(save = "no", status = issues_found)
```

</details>

And then running it like this

```shell
Rscript lintr_r_code.R $(pwd)/R-package
```

I think the issue is that `test_lint.R` includes a `skip_on_cran()`

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/b47b5ac771919f32e26c8259c060f6b1930682c8/R-package/tests/testthat/test_lint.R#L3

And R tests are run by building a package and using `R CMD check --as-cran`

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/b47b5ac771919f32e26c8259c060f6b1930682c8/tests/ci_build/build_test_rpkg.sh#L22

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/b47b5ac771919f32e26c8259c060f6b1930682c8/appveyor.yml#L106

## Proposal for fixing this issue

I think it would be beneficial to move linting out of the R unit tests into a standalone script, like the approach we use in `LightGBM` 

https://github.com/microsoft/LightGBM/blob/4d43e96bbc10de2937aa70a5829977d46bdb1852/.ci/test.sh#L57

If you do that, all `skip_*` logic can be removed, and it will be really obvious if the tests are not passing.

items.title: Predict error in R as of 1.1.1
items.body:
R version: 3.6.1 (Action of the Toes)
xgboost version: 1.1.1.1

This error can be produced when attempting to call predict on an xgboost model developed pre-1.0

Error:
` Error in predict.xgb.Booster(model, data) : 
  [11:24:23] amalgamation/../src/learner.cc:506: Check failed: mparam_.num_feature != 0 (0 vs. 0) : 0 feature is supplied.  Are you using raw Booster interface? `

items.title: Different results for some inputs with saved model on Python vs C++
fatal error during installation C1189 CUDA Toolkit v11.0
items.body:
Hi,

I tried installing the GPU-supported xgboost for R on my Windows 10 with CUDA Toolkit v11.0 + Visual Studio 2019 and got the error message during the installation:
" The version of CUB in your include path is not compatible with this release of Thrust. CUB is now included in
the CUDA Toolkit, so you no longer need to use your own checkout of CUB. Define THRUST_IGNORE_CUB_VERSION_CHECK to ignore this."

It makes me wonder if the current version support the CUDA Toolkit v11.0?

Thanks!

items.title: Parameters: { lamda, scale_pos_weight } might not be used.
items.body:
environment: anaconda 4   xgboost 1.1.1
My code in like this:
param1 = {
          "objective":"multi:softmax"
          ,"num_class":7
          ,"max_depth":5
          ,"eta":0.05
          ,"gamma":0
          ,"lamda":2
          ,"alpha":1
          ,"n_jobs":-1
          ,"eval_metric":"merror"
            ,"colsample_bytree":0.5
            ,"colsample_bylevel":0.5
            ,"scale_pos_weight":2
            ,"base_score":0.9
          }

Opening this issue from the discussion in #5778 , specifically https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/pull/5778#issuecomment-642374166.

As of this writing there is some `{lintr}`  code for linting the R package, but it is disabled https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/1d22a9be1cdeb53dfa9322c92541bc50e82f3c43/R-package/tests/testthat/test_lint.R#L26.

## How to close this issue

1.  Enable linting in `R-package/tests/testthat/test_lint.R` (or propose an alternative way to run linting checks, such as https://github.com/microsoft/LightGBM/blob/4d43e96bbc10de2937aa70a5829977d46bdb1852/.ci/test.sh#L57
2. Propose additional linters to be added. The list of available linters can be found [here](https://github.com/jimhester/lintr/tree/38279839efe0f685b281e80a77bcea1b04665f33#available-linters)

items.title: [Experience] Training exactly the same model run to run on Spark
items.body:
Xgboost on Spark actually generates different model run to run, which means if we predict the same dataset, two models from two run with exactly the same parameter and training dataset may give different prediction result. The AUC is slightly different as well.

But it's a big problem for performance optimization because the variances leads to big elapsed time difference. We can hardly know if an optimization can gain performance and how much.


There are 5 reasons for this:
- Spark may split different partitions and RDD order is random
- The partitions are scheduled to different Ranks
- Partitions are assigned to different Rank id
- allreduce_tree is built by different Rank id seq
- Reducer may reduce variable data size each time


So if one would like to generate exact the same model run to run on Spark, Here is how (.diff isn't support, I have to attach png file)

- Add two columns: partid and seqnum. Then use 
     partitionbyrange(N,"partid")     #partition number is the same as partid
     sortWithinPartitions('seqnum')
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47296334/84245296-b0329c80-aab9-11ea-8cf5-44ced58095ae.png)

- In datautil.scala, use NodeAffinityRDD to set prefered location for partid. 
      
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47296334/84245476-f25bde00-aab9-11ea-8567-e1e661291a2c.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47296334/84245629-318a2f00-aaba-11ea-956c-72df214959e7.png)
https://github.com/FelixYBW/xgboost/blob/6a409a1da0263e2b58f439d7e18f25fbca86c280/jvm-packages/xgboost4j-spark/src/main/scala/ml/dmlc/xgboost4j/scala/spark/DataUtils.scala#L36

- Assign rankid = task id = partid in dmlc-core/dmlc_tracker/tracker.py
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47296334/84246006-ce4ccc80-aaba-11ea-9e77-be894e890145.png)

- Sort Partid before allreduce_tree construction in rabit/src/allreduce_base.cc:AllreduceBase::ReConnectLinks
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47296334/84246292-4a471480-aabb-11ea-903c-7170e5fb941f.png)
https://github.com/FelixYBW/rabit/blob/e4546c5081b69fec3f79529d38967b0657f5c210/src/allreduce_base.cc#L474

- Set minimal size of reducer
      https://github.com/dmlc/rabit/pull/139

However, performance variance isn't only from the model's difference. the issued solved by Rabit PR139 is another big reason.

After the two fix, we can get very little run2run variance.

items.title: R save.xgb to json format returns unloadable model when using Minimum loss reduction parameter
items.body:
Here is some reproducible code :

```
data(agaricus.train, package='xgboost')
data(agaricus.test, package='xgboost')
train <- agaricus.train
test <- agaricus.test
bst <- xgboost(data = train$data, label = train$label, max_depth = 5, 
               eta = 1, nthread = 2, nrounds = 50,objective = "reg:logistic", gamma = 1)

# return an error (Error in xgb.Booster.handle(modelfile = modelfile) : 
  [13:43:37] amalgamation/../src/tree/tree_model.cc:702: Check failed: static_cast<bst_node_t>(deleted_nodes_.size()) == param.num_deleted (4 vs. 0) : )
xgb.save(bst, 'xgb.model.json')
bst <- xgb.load('xgb.model.json')


# works ok
xgb.save(bst, 'xgb.model')
bst <- xgb.load('xgb.model')
```

If you fit the same model with gamma = 0, you won't have any trouble to load the json file. But you probably don't want to fit a xboost without optimising the gamma parameter.

I used the version 1.0.0.2 (cran version). 

Thanks for the support,

items.title: Big model size with training continuation
items.body:
I am using XGBoost 1.1.0 and I want to apply a XGBoostRegressor on a large dataset.



1. If I train all data in once:

```
xgb_full = xgb.train(hyperparameters,
                     dtrain,
                     num_boost_round=1000,
                     evals=[(dtrain, 'train')],
                     verbose_eval=True)

model=xgb_full.save_model('model_1.model')	
```			

	 

In this case the size of model is 38 MB and I can use this it easily to predict new data.



2. If I split the same data into 100 parts and use xgb_model parameters to train continuously:

```
batch_size = 50
start = 50
xgb_partial = None
for i in range(100):
    xgb_partial = xgb.train(hyperparameters,
                            dtrain[i*start:i*start+batch_size],
                            num_boost_round=1000,
                            evals=[(dtrain[start:start+batch_size], 'train')],
                            verbose_eval=True,
                            xgb_model=xgb_partial)	
			
    model=xgb_partial.save_model('model_1.model')	

```

In this case, the saving model size at each iteration increase and at the end the size is 1,214,000 MB in my case. 

Is it normal or something is not setup properly? Is it a manageable way to regularly update the same model with new data without having a huge size of the model at the end of the training period?

items.title: c-api demo core dump
expensive CHECK_GE
items.body:
Is this CHECK_GE useful for catching any potential bug? 

https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/blob/91c646392db01714a4f69c33170fb0857b95664d/src/data/data.cc#L653-L658

It's fairly expensive for what it does; removing it reduces data loading time from ~9s to ~7s on Higgs dataset (with whole training time being ~1m on that machine, so, ~3% total.

call to LogCheck_GE is not inlined (gcc 7.4, x86):

```
#define CHECK_BINARY_OP(name, op, x, y)                               \
  if (dmlc::LogCheckError _check_err = dmlc::LogCheck##name(x, y))    \
    dmlc::LogMessageFatal(__FILE__, __LINE__).stream()                \
      << "Check failed: " << #x " " #op " " #y << *(_check_err.str) << ": "
```

disasm:

```
   cc7fa:       4d 2b 5a 10             sub    0x10(%r10),%r11
   cc7fe:       4c 89 5c 24 50          mov    %r11,0x50(%rsp)
   cc803:       e8 98 37 ff ff          callq  bffa0 <dmlc::LogCheckError dmlc::LogCheck_GE<unsigned long, unsigned long>(unsigned long const&, unsigned long const&)>
   cc808:       48 83 7c 24 58 00       cmpq   $0x0,0x58(%rsp)
```

and forcing inlining it will be likely not a good idea, as that function is pretty big. 

If the check is needed, one way to improve would be to short-circuit the condition in the macro itself and avoid the call: 

```diff
#define CHECK_BINARY_OP(name, op, x, y)                               \
+  if (!(x op y))    \
    if (dmlc::LogCheckError _check_err = dmlc::LogCheck##name(x, y))    \
    dmlc::LogMessageFatal(__FILE__, __LINE__).stream()                \
      << "Check failed: " << #x " " #op " " #y << *(_check_err.str) << ": "
```

That'd still be a 1-2 seconds win (on that, specific configuration). I can make a change, but if it's ok to just remove the check, that would be easier.

items.title: xgboost training continuation convergence problem
items.body:
Hello :)

I was using xgboost to train in a large dataset (using dmatrix external memory feature) and using the AWS Sagemaker with spot training enabled, so my training job can be interrupted at any moment. So, I needed to save xgboost.train() checkpoints. I was saving it at each round, but the model was giving a much worse score than the full trained one with just a subset of the data. So I decided to make some small tests on the iris dataset and I got to the following results:

1 - Full train:
```
xgb_full = xgb.train(hyperparameters,
                     dtrain,
                     num_boost_round=100,
                     evals=[(dtrain, 'train')],
                     feval=f1_score_dmatrix,
                     maximize=True,
                     verbose_eval=True)
```
 This one converges to `train-error:0.00833	train-f1:0.98667`

2 - Checkpoint at each round:
```
xgb_partial = None
for _ in range(100):
    xgb_partial = xgb.train(hyperparameters,
                            dtrain,
                            num_boost_round=1,
                            evals=[(dtrain, 'train')],
                            feval=f1_score_dmatrix,
                            maximize=True,
                            verbose_eval=True,
                            xgb_model=xgb_partial)
```
This one converges to `train-error:0.04167	train-f1:0.93671`

3 - Checkpoint at each 10 rounds:
```
xgb_partial = None
for _ in range(10):
    xgb_partial = xgb.train(hyperparameters,
                            dtrain,
                            num_boost_round=10,
                            evals=[(dtrain, 'train')],
                            feval=f1_score_dmatrix,
                            maximize=True,
                            verbose_eval=True,
                            xgb_model=xgb_partial)
```
This one converges to `train-error:0.01667	train-f1:0.97368`

In that way, is this a known issue for training continuation feature and/or expected behavior?

The full test script code can be found in this [gist](https://gist.github.com/ronaldpereira/5ded29087c07a7c793783d8dd0390258)
